utterances: It wasn't.
There was no mention of canine teams.
I know that the TSA has been expanding its use of canine teams.
I don't think they're doing it in cargo, but they definitely do use canine teams, dogs, in inspecting luggage.
And I don't know the reason for not doing that.
I don't know how reliable they are, but I guess if the TSA is using them for luggage, then they must consider them reliable.
That's a good point.
I don't know the answer to that.
Well, I know when I was working our dog, we had a 100 percent find rate over the course of three years.
It would take us about 15 minutes to clear a good-sized room, maybe 20 to 25 minutes at the most, to clear aircraft, passenger and cargo compartments.
So it just seems to me to make sense to utilize what we've already got and we know how to use.
Well, one thing to keep in mind is that when you're talking about inspecting cargo going on an airplane, you're not talking about one airplane leaving a day.
You're talking about, at a large airport, hundreds of airplanes leaving a day.
And I don't know whether you could have a team of dogs working whatever--16 hours a day, non-stop.
I think that there may be an issue...
Well, no, it would have to rotate through multiple teams, of course, but...
Right, and what I'm saying is...
Meant to be a round-the-clock operation, you're saying, Tom.
...is that--right.
It's one thing to test things in a laboratory or use things every so often, but the airport environment is an incredibly difficult environment.

So when you're talking about using some kind of technology, even if it's dogs, you have to make sure that dogs can actually operate in an airport and do, you know, hundreds, thousands of packages for hours and hours a day.
All right.
Thanks for your call, Myles.
What is considered high-risk cargo?
I mean, what cargo--do they ever pull things out that they do inspect?
I mean...
They do.
As I said, the inspection is done randomly.
What's high-risk cargo they won't tell you.
They won't say.
They won't say.
No.
Yeah.
Uh-huh.

The things that are looked at in terms of evaluating cargo is that the TSA likes to look at the chain, the supply chain--how something gets--where it went--you know, what path it traveled to get to the point where it's ready to be loaded in an airplane.
And the TSA--one of the devices it has is something called the known shipper program.

The idea is that if Wal-Mart is shipping something and you know Wal-Mart is safe and Wal-Mart can prove to the government that it has a very secure supply chain, then that can be considered safe cargo.
So it's, I think, done largely by analyzing where has a certain item that's going to be shipped--where has it been?
Let's see if we can take another call from Tony, and he's calling from Huntington, West Virginia.
Hi, Tony.
It's funny that he just mentioned that program, because that's what I was going to comment on.
Right about two weeks after 9/11--we ship TV production equipment from Detroit to Tampa, Florida.
And we found out to our dismay at the last minute that they'd changed the rules.
We've been doing it for years, but all of a sudden we weren't a known shipper.
We had to fill out all kinds of paperwork and we couldn't get the stuff on the plane right then.
So you couldn't just take a giant box up and say, `Send this to my Aunt Mary,' unless they already knew you.
And our stuff was, you know, TV monitors, cameras, all kinds of electronic stuff that, if it were scanned, they wouldn't have no idea whether it was a bomb or not.
Yeah.
Well, once you've done that, once you've gone through that process, is it easier the next time?
Are you then a known shipper?
Yes.
Yes.
Yes, because they recognize--they look at the history.
They realize you've been doing that for years.
The exact same products have been shipping back and forth between those two airports, and/or similar equipment, and they know who you are and they check into it.
And then, you know, there's no problem.
All right.
Thanks so much for your call, Tony.
OK.
Thank you.
Tom, did the report recommend any action--specific action be taken?
It recommended a lot of action.

Mostly, it talked about the need for the TSA to do sort of, I guess, a top-to-bottom, beginning-to-end analysis of the supply chain, and to actually try to find all the specific vulnerabilities in the aviation security system, and take more of a risk-based approach.
That's something that the government likes to do.
If you have limited resources, apply them where the risk is the greatest.
All right.
Thanks so much for joining us.
Tom Frank is the Washington correspondent for USA Today, and you can read the GAO's report on air cargo security at our Web site, npr.org.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Lynn Neary.
This escalating violence in the Middle East is overshadowing this weekend's meetings at the Group of Eight economic powers in St. Petersburg, Russia.
President Bush spoke about the situation during a news conference with Russian President Vladimir Putin earlier today.
President GEORGE W.
BUSH: The solution, short-term solution, is for Hezbollah to stop the attacks.
The longer-term solution is for nations around the world and nations in the neighborhood to support those who support the advance of democracy.
Presidents Bush and Putin are holding their own one-on-one meetings in advance of the official start of the G8 Summit this evening.
It's the first time that Russia has hosted the Summit and it comes as President Bush's special relationship with President Putin is coming under increasing scrutiny and strain.
NPR's Don Gonyea joins us from St. Petersburg.
Don, thanks for being with us.
Hi, Scott.
And what's the president want to accomplish?
Well, he did announce an agreement to coordinate efforts to stop the transfer of illicit weapons around the world.
So that's something concrete that they've announced already today.
Additionally, obviously there are all these pressing issues out there.
There's the Middle East, the current crisis.
Both these leaders said they want the violence to stop, but they differ.
Putin says Israel's use of force needs to be balanced.
That was the word he used, balanced.
On Iran, the U.S.
wants sanctions, Putin has resisted.
Mr. Bush is trying to win him over.
Both do say there should be no nuclear weapons in Iran.
They both agree on that broad point.
Same with North Korea.
President Bush wants to further isolate that nation in the wake of those missile tests from earlier this month.
He'd like Putin's backing, but again no resolution on that here today.
Don, a while back President Bush famously announced that he had shaken Mr. Putin's hands and looked into his eyes and was able to get a sense of his soul, and liked it.
A lot of history has happened then.
What's been the single biggest irritant in U.S./Russian relations?
It's what the U.S.
sees as Putin's increasingly authoritarian hand.
There's worry about human rights and a crackdown on the press in Russia and a crackdown on political dissidence.
President Bush is very diplomatic when he talks publicly about this.

Today he said he always raises such concerns in person with Putin, and in private, and he said he learns a lot from the discussion, and today at one point he said he doesn't insist that Russia have a U.S.-style democracy.
Well, we have a - let's listen to what President Putin says about - someone asked a question about the state of Russian democracy.
(Through Translator) Nobody knows better than us how we can strengthen our own nation.
But we know for sure that we cannot strengthen our nation without developing democratic institutions and this is the path that we'll certainly take, but certainly we will do this by ourselves.
It doesn't sound like he's asking for a lot of input from President Bush or much of anyone else.
Indeed.

At one point, President Bush mentioned the new democracy in Iraq during that press conference and Putin quickly jumped in and said, and this is a quote, we certainly would not want to have the same kind of democracy as they have in Iraq.
So it seemed like more than a bit of a dig there.
Rest of the G8 leaders are going to be arriving in St. Petersburg today.
How are they are going to be able to focus on economic issues and other concerns, given this breaking news from the Mid East?
There's a lot of structure to a G8 meeting and the agenda, run by Russia, remains, and formal talks will proceed as planned.
But look for discussion on the Middle East to occupy the less structured sessions and any one-on-one sessions that are held between individual leaders who are coming here.
NPR's Don Gonyea speaking with us from the site of the G8 Summit meeting in St. Petersburg, Russia.
Don, thank you very much for being with us.
Sally Lohrbach of Gulfport, Mississippi, works for the Salvation Army in Biloxi.
And our coverage of Hurricane Katrina's aftermath, including other accounts from people affected by the storm, continues at npr.org.
And he - (foreign language spoken)
The treatment of these women is very much tied into gender discrimination, racial discrimination.
All of these attitudes really play into employers seeing domestic workers as not quite human.
Back in the suburbs of Washington, Kumari Sabbithi was depressed and considering suicide.
Finally, she confronted the couple in October 2005.
Speaking up for the first time, she complained that they owed her a month's salary.
She says the diplomat's wife called her ungrateful for all the good things they'd given her.
Sabbithi describes the conversation in English.
Madam say I give you the food, I give you the soap, I give you the clothes.
Everything, everything, I give it.
So I said, Madam, give me my money.
She says the wife was furious and threatened to cut off her tongue and that the woman's husband, the diplomat, pushed her to the floor.
The suit says Sabbithi hit her head on a kitchen table and blacked out.
When she came to, her co-workers urged her to flee for her life.
Sabbithi said she feared she might never return to India and see her husband and two young daughters.
I think I'm still there, that people is killing, I never can see my family.
I think about it and I left that house.
She gathered a few belongings, including underwear and a Bible.
As the family relaxed in the basement, she slipped away.
(Through translator) I came out of the house around 7:15 in the evening.
I started walking.
